title: Brazen food stamp scammers steal millions from L.A.’s poorest

last_post.content:
Terrific reporting by Rebecca Ellis at The Los Angeles Times on the scope of the card skimming fraud targeting people who receive state food and other financial assistance via debit cards (a.k.a Electronic Benefits Cards or EBTs).

The story makes clear again that the organized crime groups involved will wait until funds are deposited by the state onto these EBT cards. That happens early in the morning, and the fraudsters are hitting the ATMs with the cloned EBT cards just as soon as the funds are there.

From the story:

"Skyrocketing theft amounts
In 2019, Los Angeles County saw $25,227 in EBT benefits stolen, according to the Department of Public Social Services. In 2020, $340,891 was taken. In 2021, the number began to skyrocket: $914,003 was stolen, most of it in the last few months of the year."

https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2023-02-08/ebt-fraud-la-county

I covered EBT skimming in a couple of recent posts:

https://krebsonsecurity.com/2022/10/how-card-skimming-disproportionally-affects-those-most-in-need/

https://krebsonsecurity.com/2022/11/lawsuit-seeks-food-benefits-stolen-by-skimmers/

title: Bots in Congress: The Risks and Benefits of Emerging AI Tools in the Legislative Branch

last_post.content:
"On net, new technologies have facilitated increased productivity, greater transparency, and more ways for direct democratic engagement. But they have also created new challenges, in the form of new expectations, perverse incentives, and disruptions. Generative AI tools will be no different. Congress must take a deliberate approach to test and learn how these technologies can be applied, and to set boundaries that acknowledge their limitations."

title: Napoléon Part I - From Corsica to Paris - La Fayette, We Are Here!

last_post.content:
#OTD in 1807, pyrrhic and indecisive French victory at the battle of Eylau, against the Russians and Prussians. The losses are so horrible that Napoléon stated: “If all the kings of the earth could view such a spectacle, they would be less keen on wars and conquest”.

One of the most remarkable moments of the battle was Murat’s cavalry charge. At 12,000 strong, it is one of the biggest cavalry charges ever. It was essential in preventing a French collapse during the battle. Nevertheless, Ney will say “What a massacre! And all this for nothing!”

The war will drag on for months. Only the decisive French victory of Friedland in June 1807 will lead to the treaty of Tilsit with Alexander I a month later, ending the war of the 4th Coalition and making Russia France’s partner in the continental system… for a time anyway.

To learn more about Napoléon’s rise to power, listen to our latest episode.

Listen on: https://www.lafayettepodcast.com/1969630/12142936-napoleon-part-i-from-corsica-to-paris

title: [experiment] Run babel over output for let/const to var by jakebailey · Pull Request #52656 · microsoft/TypeScript

last_post.content:
An excellent JS performance experiment by @jakebailey ⚡

Modifying the TypeScript compiler itself so that `let`/`const` become `var` reduces parsing time by ~10% 😲

This is on V8 10.2

One theory is that the perf penalty is due to TDZ checks when using `let`/`const`

Maybe results in Bun/JSC will be different?

Nothing is conclusive. The PR is unlikely to be merged.

The investigation continues... 😉

https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/pull/52656#issuecomment-1421249664
